questions.text: A scientist is studying different types of glucose transporters found in human tissues. He observes that some transporters have a higher affinity for glucose than others. Which transporters have the highest affinity for glucose uptake?
questions.solution:
Glucose is one of the human tissues' main sources of cellular respiration, which is used to make energy. There are seven important types of glucose transporters in the human body, which include glucose transporters 1 through 5 (GLUT 1-5) and sodium-glucose cotransporters (SGLT) 1 and 2 (found in the small intestines and kidneys, respectively).  

Each transporter is found in different body tissues and has a different affinity for glucose based on its Michaelis-Menten constant (Km), which can be defined most simply as the amount of substrate necessary to allow an enzyme or peptide to function at half its maximal velocity.  

Glucose transporter 3 (GLUT3) is found in the brain, neurons, and placenta. It is known to have the lowest Km (resulting in the highest affinity) for glucose among all the GLUTs. This characteristic is important since the brain and placenta are vital and need to have glucose available at all times, even in insufficient quantities (e.g., starvation, critical illness), to ensure adequate amounts are present for metabolism and ATP formation.   

Option Analysis

❌ Glucose transporter 2 (GLUT2):
Incorrect: GLUT2 is found in beta islet cells of the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and gastrointestinal (GI) tract tissues. Though it is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation, it has a low affinity for glucose. It only uptakes glucose at higher serum levels (for storage and glucose-mediated insulin release).  
✅ Glucose transporter 3 (GLUT3):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Glucose transporter 4 (GLUT4)  :
Incorrect: GLUT4, also known as an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, is mainly found in adipose tissues and striated muscles. Exercise and insulin increase their expression, increasing intracellular glucose and ATP generation from glucose metabolism. It has a moderate affinity for glucose.  
❌ Glucose transporter 5 (GLUT5)  :
Incorrect: GLUT5 is found in spermatocytes and gastrointestinal (GI) tract tissues. Though it is not dependent on insulin for its expression and upregulation, it is mainly a fructose transporter.
❌ Sodium-glucose co-transporter (SGLT1)  :
Incorrect: SGLT1 is an ATP and sodium-dependent transporter found on the luminal surface of enterocytes of the intestinal epithelium. It helps in glucose absorption and does not have the highest affinity for glucose.

questions.text: A graduate student is conducting research on pancreatic physiology. For one of their experiments, a culture flask containing pancreatic beta cells is prepared. Afterward, glucose is added to the flask. The intracellular ATP/ADP ratio, magnitude of the outflowing potassium current, and magnitude of the inflowing calcium current are measured. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be observed?
questions.solution:
Insulin is a type of peptide hormone that reduces the amount of glucose in the blood. It is produced in pancreatic beta cells. Insulin’s main function is to facilitate the transport of glucose from the blood into the various insulin-responsive tissues like muscle cells and adipose tissue.  

Insulin is released from beta cells via a four-step process. First, extracellular glucose is transported into beta cells via GLUT2 receptors. Second, inside the cell, glucose undergoes glycolysis to produce ATP. Third, the ATP binds to and closes potassium channels. This causes a decrease in the outflowing potassium current, resulting in cellular depolarization. Fourth, depolarization opens voltage-gated calcium channels, which increases intracellular calcium and causes insulin secretion.  

Once released, insulin binds to its receptors in the target tissue (e.g., adipose, liver, muscle) and causes intracellular storage vesicles, which contain glucose transport proteins called GLUT4, to fuse with the cellular membrane. The GLUT4 proteins then embed themselves into the membrane and allow glucose to enter the cell, ultimately reducing blood glucose levels.  

Option Analysis

❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↓  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: In this experiment, glucose is administered to beta cells. The elevated glucose would lead to increased glycolysis and an elevated ATP/ADP ratio. The newly synthesized ATP then closes potassium channels, resulting in a decrease in the magnitude of the outflowing potassium current. 
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↓  ↓ ↑ :
Incorrect: Increased glucose concentrations would result in increased glycolysis, resulting in an elevated ATP/ADP ratio.
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Increased glucose concentrations would result in increased glycolysis, resulting in an elevated ATP/ADP ratio. However, the ATP then closes potassium channels, which decreases the outflowing potassium current.
✅  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  ATP/ADP Ratio  Potassium Current Magnitude  Calcium Current Magnitude  ↑  ↓ ↓:
Incorrect: An increase in extracellular glucose concentration leads to an increased ATP/ADP ratio and a decrease in the magnitude of the outflowing potassium current. The latter depolarizes the beta cell and causes voltage-gated calcium channels to open, resulting in an increase in the magnitude of the inflowing calcium current.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass. She first noticed the mass five weeks ago, following an upper respiratory infection. She has not experienced any dyspnea or dysphagia. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 109/72 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. On physical examination, a midline mass is observed over the anterior neck around 1 centimeter below the hyoid bone. The mass is soft and nontender to palpation. The mass moves when the patient swallows. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct
Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless, midline neck mass that moves with swallowing. These findings suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst, an embryologic remnant that forms when the thyroglossal duct fails to close after birth.  

During embryological development, the thyroid gland originates in the floor of the embryonic pharynx in an area called the foramen cecum, found on the dorsum of the tongue. The thyroid gland subsequently migrates from the tongue into the neck, passing anterior to the hyoid bone through the thyroglossal duct. This duct normally disappears after birth; however, in some cases, part of this duct remains, and a thyroglossal duct cyst can develop.  

Thyroglossal duct cysts are typically located along the anterior midline portion of the neck. They can form a visual and palpable mass. The cysts move with swallowing or tongue movement, which can help distinguish them from other neck masses (e.g. malignant tumors). Most cases are asymptomatic, but some can cause neck pain or dysphagia if they grow large or become infected. In rare cases, a thyroglossal duct cyst carcinoma can develop from ectopic thyroid tissue within the cyst. Other complications may include infections, rupture, and formation of a thyroglossal fistula.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatous thyroid gland inflammation:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, also called de Quervain thyroiditis. The condition typically presents as a painful swelling of the thyroid gland following an upper respiratory infection. In contrast, this patient’s mass is painless.
✅ Incomplete obliteration of the thyroglossal duct:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Outpouching of the cervical esophagus:
Incorrect: A Zenker diverticulum is characterized by outpouching of the esophageal mucosa through an area of muscle weakness in the posterior esophageal wall. The condition most commonly develops at Killian’s triangle and involves the cervical esophagus. The condition can present with dysphagia, regurgitation, cough, aspiration, and foul-smelling breath. However, it would not typically present as an anterior neck mass.
❌ Failed obliteration of a branchial cleft:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a branchial cleft cyst. The condition typically presents as a nontender, lateral neck mass. In contrast, this patient has a midline neck mass that moves when she swallows, suggesting a thyroglossal duct cyst.  
❌ Malignant proliferation of thyrocytes:
Incorrect: Thyroid cancer is characterized by malignant proliferation of thyroid gland tissue. The condition presents as a firm and usually painless nodule. If the cancer invades surrounding tissue, the tumor can remain fixed and will not move with swallowing or tongue movements. In contrast, this patient has a soft and mobile neck mass, which suggests a thyroglossal duct cyst.

questions.text:
A three-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with fatigue and concern for seizures. His parents describe that he has not been acting like himself lately and has had intermittent sustained jerking movements of his arms and legs. In addition, the patient has had intermittent vomiting and diarrhea but no fevers. He has met most developmental milestones but has difficulty copying a circle with a pencil and does not understand what “two” means. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. His workup is notable for a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, and a chemistry panel yields the following results:



Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal tissue
Accumulation of phytanic acid in plasma and peripheral tissue
De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome
Inability to convert hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with adrenal insufficiency (e.g., nausea, vomiting), as well as seizures and cognitive delay. Laboratory testing demonstrates a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which are consistent with a diagnosis of adrenoleukodystrophy.  

Adrenoleukodystrophy is a rare inborn error of metabolism that is inherited in an X-linked recessive fashion. The disease is due to accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal, central nervous, and gonadal tissues as a consequence of impaired beta oxidation in peroxisomes. Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in these tissues manifests with primary adrenal insufficiency, seizures, and hypogonadism.  

The disease is variable and manifests in childhood or adulthood, but overwhelmingly the first clinical sign of the disease is adrenal insufficiency. If untreated, the disease can lead to worsening cognitive decline, dementia, cortical blindness, quadriparesis, coma, and death.  

Diagnosis of the disease involves performing genetic analysis for mutations in the ABCD1 gene. Treatment is multifactorial and depends on the clinical stage of diagnosis. If diagnosed in childhood, allogeneic stem cell transplant is often recommended in addition to life-long hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency. If diagnosed as an adult, treatment is primarily supportive in addition to life-long hydrocortisone.



Option Analysis

✅ Accumulation of very long chain fatty acids in adrenal tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of phytanic acid in plasma and peripheral tissue:
Incorrect: Refsum disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder affecting alpha-oxidation of fatty acids. The condition manifests with scaly skin, ataxia, and cataracts/night blindness. Treatment involves plasmapheresis. However, this patient has no cutaneous findings, and Refsum disease is not associated with a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
❌ Deficiency of arylsulfatase A enzyme:
Incorrect: Metachromatic leukodystrophy manifests with central and peripheral demyelination, ataxia, and dementia. The condition arises due to deficient arylsulfatase A enzyme and accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. However, the disorder is not associated with a mutation in the ABCD1 gene.
❌ De novo mutation of MECP2 on X chromosome:
Incorrect: Rett syndrome manifests with regressive motor, verbal, and cognitive features as well as ataxia, seizures, growth failure, and stereotyped hand movements. It is due to a mutation of the MECP2 gene. Rett syndrome would not account for the hyponatremia and hyperkalemia seen on this patient’s laboratory testing.
❌ Inability to convert hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP:
Incorrect: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by a defective purine salvage pathway due to absence of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), which converts hypoxanthine to IMP and guanine to GMP. Clinically, this disease manifests with intellectual disability, self-mutilation, aggression, and gout.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting and lethargy. The patient has had several days of difficulty feeding, frequent spitting, and poor weight gain. His mother is worried that he might be dehydrated. The patient was born at home and did not have any prenatal screening performed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 70/min, blood pressure is 40/19 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. On physical exam the infant has poor tone, sunken fontanelles, and dry mucous membranes. Initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below:



Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This neonate presents with dehydration, shock, and adrenal insufficiency as evidenced by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia. These findings raise concern for 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which is associated with elevated renin levels due to absence of suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.  

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which are a series of autosomal recessive enzymatic deficiency disorders that disrupt synthesis of mineralocorticoids, glucocorticoids, and sex hormones. 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes decreased glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid synthesis and elevated precursors--the most important of which is 17-hydroxyprogesterone, which is used for the diagnosis of this condition. Ultimately, cortisol and aldosterone are not produced in this disorder, resulting in elevated levels of renin, ACTH, and increased production of androgen precursors.  

21-hydroxylase deficiency has differing clinical manifestations depending on the degree of enzyme deficiency and sex at birth. In severe deficiency, both male and female infants present with significant salt-wasting syndrome characterized by shock, dehydration, and adrenal crisis. Most female neonates will have ambiguous genitalia at birth due to androgen excess. Moderate deficiency will result in ambiguous genitalia in females, whereas males will demonstrate early virilization (at age 2-4) due to androgen excess. Mild enzyme deficiency will result in hirsutism and menstrual irregularities in females, whereas males develop early-onset puberty.  

The majority of patients born in the developed world are screened after birth by measuring 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels. Diagnosis of the disorder is achieved through screening for adrenal insufficiency and enzymatic activity assays. Treatment involves life-long replacement of gluco- and mineralocorticoids.



Option Analysis

✅ Increased renin activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased renin activity:
Incorrect: Decreased renin activity is associated with 11ꞵ-hydroxylase and 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. These conditions lead to elevated levels of hormones with mild mineralocorticoid activity (e.g., 11-deoxycorticosterone, aldosterone), resulting in hypertension, hypokalemia, and suppression of the renin-angiotensin axis.
❌ Decreased levels of androstenedione  :
Incorrect: Decreased levels of androstenedione are associated with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with ambiguous genitalia in males and lack of secondary sex characteristics in females.
❌ Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone are observed in 17α-hydroxylase deficiency due to shunting of pregnenolone towards aldosterone production. This disorder manifests with hypokalemia and hypertension. In contrast, this patient has hyperkalemia and hypotension.
❌ Increased levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone only:
Incorrect: Elevated levels of 11-deoxycorticosterone without elevated levels of corticosterone are observed in patients with 11ꞵ-hydroxylase deficiency, which manifests with hypokalemia and hypertension. In contrast, this patient has hyperkalemia and hypotension.
